page.title: 02The Great Landslip of 1839
page.content: Mr Barns pointed out to us that Dowlands was the site of the Great Landslip of Christmas, 1839 when 8,000,000 tons of land subsided taking cottages, orchards and fields with it,to form the feature known as Goat Island and the great chasm between it and the mainland cliff. Fortunately the cottagers living there, used as they were to the occasional falls of chalk from the cliff face, had some early warnings and moved out of their houses before the 8,000,000 tons of land slipped into the sea. According to Mr Barns's pamphlet, obtainable from the Seaton TIC, this was the greatest landslip ever to occur in Britain. The deep chasm or ravine is more than a half mile in length approaching 80 yards in breadth and varying in depth from 100 to 150 feet.
